title: Airlines' bid to force airports to arbitration rejected
text:
Commissioner Dr Stephen King told The Australian Financial Review the biggest risk with the negotiate-arbitrate model was that it could be gamed by incumbent airlines.

"The way that they can game it is to try and set base prices and standards that will make it difficult for their competitors, particularly their discount competitors," Dr King said. "We see that commercial negotiation has worked over the last 17 years."

Although airlines can apply to have airport services "declared" under the National Access Regime (which can lead to the ACCC overseeing access), airlines say the process of declaration is time-consuming and costly.

But the commission said overriding the declaration and appeal processes would allow a commercial arbitrator to compel airports to provide services to airlines at a specific price, but would not be able to compel airlines to use airport services at that price.

Divisions remain

Australian Airports Association chief executive Caroline Wilkie said common sense had prevailed in the debate over whether a new arbitration framework was needed and airlines had failed to make the case for more regulation.

But A4ANZ said the government should not adopt the final report's recommendations.

Advertisement

“Better, fairer deals for airport users are what is needed, not five more years of the same issues and worse," said A4ANZ chairman Professor Graeme Samuels.

The Federal government said it was considering the report and would respond in due course.

The commission wants the ACCC to collect more data on costs and revenues for international and domestic services to increase scrutiny of airport performance, and to publish a database.

Brisbane Airport’s aeronautical charges for international services are the highest of the four monitored airports, and are also high compared with overseas airports.

"We need to keep an eye on international charges at Brisbane Airport, but the monitoring data we have at the moment isn’t adequate for us to definitively say whether there is a problem in Brisbane,” Dr King said.

The commission has backed a review of how take-off and landing slots are awarded to airlines at Sydney Airport. The current system gives preference to incumbent airlines, making it harder for other airlines to compete.
description: The Productivity Commission's final report disputed airlines' claims that the current light-handed regulatory system for airports pushes up airfares.
